comment.narrative: A major failing was the exclusion of women from the formal peace structure, despite provisions made within the official frameworks for women’s participation. This demonstrates a lack of a gender equitable approach in Myanmar’s national peace process, where women’s participation is extremely limited not only at the highest levels but also at the operational levels such as in ceasefire monitoring and substantive peace negotiations.
Network of women peace ambassadors advocate jointly for women nomination and participation in the formal peace process at various levels.

Prior to the coup, women were already highly active in the informal peace process and forming networks of collaboration. The coup has galvanized these networks, which have a longstanding reputation of organizing and engagement due to their strong civil society activism, primarily through ethnic women’s organizations.

The coup has galvanized these networks, which have a longstanding reputation of organizing and engagement due to their strong civil society activism, primarily through ethnic women’s organizations.

description.narrative: Women’s caucuses and networks are strengthened
Women’s caucuses and networks are strengthened

comment.narrative: Although few women from political and civil society in Myanmar succeeded in breaking into the formal peace negotiations, they are key players within informal peacebuilding, helping resolve issues around land rights and create greater social cohesion. There lacks recognition of the peacebuilding work that women perform in informal spaces, as well as recognition of their voices in the formal peace processes.
